reference: Volume Three, Issue Thirty-Four, File #8 of 11
title: A TCP/IP Tutorial : Behind The Internet Part Two of Two
historical_context: This article was written during the early days of the Internet, providing foundational knowledge about TCP/IP protocols that are still relevant today.
target_audience: Network administrators, security professionals, and anyone interested in understanding TCP/IP protocols.
short_summary: This article provides a comprehensive overview of the Internet Protocol (IP) and its routing mechanisms, including direct and indirect routing, IP address assignment, and the role of UDP and TCP in network communications.
summary:
In this second part of the TCP/IP tutorial, the author delves into the intricacies of the Internet Protocol (IP), emphasizing the importance of the route table in determining how IP packets are routed across networks. The article explains both direct and indirect routing, illustrating how packets are forwarded through routers and how IP addresses are structured. It also discusses the significance of route tables and how they are managed by network administrators to ensure effective communication across different IP networks.

The tutorial further explores the User Datagram Protocol (UDP) and the Transmission Control Protocol (TCP), highlighting their distinct functionalities. UDP is presented as a connectionless protocol that prioritizes speed over reliability, making it suitable for applications like Network File System (NFS) and Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP). In contrast, TCP is described as a connection-oriented protocol that guarantees delivery, making it ideal for applications requiring reliable data transmission, such as File Transfer Protocol (FTP) and TELNET. The article concludes with a brief mention of security considerations within the TCP/IP suite, hinting at the complexities and challenges that arise in network security.
